Refers to: debian/postinst:12 in ef01c58. [](commit_id = ef01c58e8793c4dcee4bef4b6402fc52963654bf, deletion_comment = False)

> >

> Refers to: debian/postinst:12 in [ef01c58](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/commit/ef01c58e8793c4dcee4bef4b6402fc52963654bf). [](commit_id = [ef01c58](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/commit/ef01c58e8793c4dcee4bef4b6402fc52963654bf), deletion_comment = False)

Hi Qi, conffiles works, but there is one concern. When we use conffiles, if the config file already exists, installing deb pkg will give a prompt as below. The user needs to decide what to do next.
Did somne search, looks there is no better to skip this prompt in deb pkg installing. If we use this way,  we need to add options when issusing "sudo dpkg -i --force-confold libswsscommon_1.0.0_amd64.deb" with --force-confold option to skip the prompt. Which means we need to modify all the build script which is using "dpkg -i libswsscommon_1.0.0_amd64.deb". This seems not good to me, it introduce more changes and did not get any big benefits. It also force installing to not overwrite existing files, which may be not good in future when there is a need to overwrite. Using manually copy in postinst can avoid this problem and didn't introduce extra changes.


```
Configuration file '/var/run/redis/sonic-db/database_config.json'
 ==> File on system created by you or by a script.
 ==> File also in package provided by package maintainer.
   What would you like to do about it ?  Your options are:
    Y or I  : install the package maintainer's version
    N or O  : keep your currently-installed version
      D     : show the differences between the versions
      Z     : start a shell to examine the situation
 The default action is to keep your current version.
*** database_config.json (Y/I/N/O/D/Z) [default=N] ? Y
```

Thanks @dzhangalibaba !

Could you please share your code about "conffiles works" in another PR? I would like to explorer further. To suppress dpkg prompt is the right thing to do in future.

> Thanks @dzhangalibaba !
> 
> Could you please share your code about "conffiles works" in another PR? I would like to explorer further. To suppress dpkg prompt is the right thing to do in future.

FYI, https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/pull/323

Just as a question, our future goal is  to support multiple syncd's running across system, controlled by single OA agent, some requirements i posted in my long email:
* each syncd must have global unique id (0..255 etc)
* each syncd must have database assigned (redis db index)
* each syncd must support multiple switches, and each switch must have defined HWINFO for it (SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_SWITCH_HARDWARE_INFO (and maybe also SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_SWITCH_PROFILE_ID)  this information is needed to uniquely identify every switch instance globally

**my question here is whether we want this information in this file or do we need other file?** this switch/syncd info is something more than db config, but it strictly depends on database configuration which is defined in this file

note: different syncd instances can ha same database server used, but asic_db index must be different for each syncd instance

> Just as a question, our future goal is to support multiple syncd's running across system, controlled by single OA agent, some requirements i posted in my long email:
> 
> * each syncd must have global unique id (0..255 etc)
> * each syncd must have database assigned (redis db index)
> * each syncd must support multiple switches, and each switch must have defined HWINFO for it (SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_SWITCH_HARDWARE_INFO (and maybe also SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_SWITCH_PROFILE_ID)  this information is needed to uniquely identify every switch instance globally
> 
> **my question here is whether we want this information in this file or do we need other file?** this switch/syncd info is something more than db config, but it strictly depends on database configuration which is defined in this file
> 
> note: different syncd instances can ha same database server used, but asic_db index must be different for each syncd instance

I think we need extend current conf file to support the case you mention. And then add the backend logic to parse conf file to finish the work what you case want
seems good to me

@qiluo-msft @kcudnik @lguohan 
adding db config file into build docker definitely will solve the issue. Now the question is "do we really want to add it into build docker ?"  What's the difference between build docker having a default db config file at /var/run/redis/sonic-db/ and submodule Makefile coping(mkdir/mkdir) a db config file into /var/run/redis/sonic-db/  at build time ? They all changed the building system. The feedback at sairedis PR suggest NOT copy db config file into build system.  

BTW , I am happy to have a db config by default in build docker, in this way, we don't need to worry about all the submodules who might miss db config file when doing some tests while building time. It will save my life. Can we go ahead with this approach ? Let me know and I can go head to adding it into build docker OR change each individual test case to have this db config file while building.

seems fine to me, that config needs to be copied to build docker anyway
but you can still address at() methods and file open check if file exists

> seems fine to me, that config needs to be copied to build docker anyway
> but you can still address at() methods and file open check if file exists

yes. I can start address the at() and file checking first. 

Let's see what's the opinion on adding db config file into build docker from Guohan and Qi. Then we can decide what to do this next.

From: Shuotian Cheng <notifications@github.com>
Sent: Thursday, September 5, 2019 4:13 PM
To: Azure/sonic-swss-common <sonic-swss-common@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Renuka Manavalan <Renuka.Manavalan@microsoft.com>; Assign <assign@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [Azure/sonic-swss-common] timerfd return 0 with errno =0 - handle as False alarm. (#302)

—
You are receiving this because you were assigned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2FAzure%2Fsonic-swss-common%2Fpull%2F302%3Femail_source%3Dnotifications%26email_token%3DALIXUJMUF2CDTQYGPZ2IQPTQIGG6BA5CNFSM4IUCNBZKYY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFVREXG43VMVBW63LNMVXHJKTDN5WW2ZLOORPWSZGOD6BG4YQ%23issuecomment-528641634&data=02%7C01%7CRenuka.Manavalan%40microsoft.com%7C4888835a935e4cafdc8708d7325687ce%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C637033219536307865&sdata=kvtKyRVvorfwtRnzRsOEmXr9gpP%2BdNzktnvdfzCzN%2F8%3D&reserved=0>, or mute the thread<https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fnotifications%2Funsubscribe-auth%2FALIXUJOQ2WOA22LH4FTT46DQIGG6BANCNFSM4IUCNBZA&data=02%7C01%7CRenuka.Manavalan%40microsoft.com%7C4888835a935e4cafdc8708d7325687ce%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C637033219536317879&sdata=SjMTJz5VenN9HXrOYlDUdD9AmrHRK3zp61VBjNHiEWA%3D&reserved=0>.

@aruljeniston
Do we know the reasons why the kernel returns 0? Until we know this, we can't fix anything and be sure everything will work.
I checked the kernel code and I saw that it's impossible to get 0.
But we getting 0, which means either our compiler generated bad code or the platform works incorrectly. Can we investigate why it's possible to get 0?
I can provide results I found in the kernel code.
@renukamanavalan Do you know what kernel bug exactly we're facing? Can we fix it?

@pavel-shirshov 
You have already stated the bug, "_Do we know the reasons why the kernel returns 0_".

timerfd::read is expected to return non-zero value or error (ret = -1 && errno != 0). But we do get return value of 0. 
Q: How do we handle it (as there is no kernel fix) ?
Provided a couple of ways above. 

If you have some suggestions on other ways of working around it, please provide.

"Do we know the reasons why the kernel returns 0".
- Kernel could return 0 for real-time TFD_TIMER_ABSTIME timers. It has been communicated to Linux community and they are planning to change the man page of timerfd for real-time timers. 
you may read the last two posts of this mail thread https://lists.gt.net/linux/kernel/3435187 . 
- We do see a possibility in the code where timerfd::read() could return 0 on monotonic timers but Linux community says it is only possible if hardware clocks (tsc in this case) are not in sync. We have been running several tests but haven't seen any problem in the hardware so far.
- Our preference is to pick option 2 as it doesn't have any side effect.

@aruljeniston 
Thank you for the information.
We have two things here:
1. The poll() returned us that a timer object fired, but when we read, we got 0.
2. read() returned 0.

I read the thread and found that you didn't discuss 1., but only 2.

Do we know when poll could return us timer event?
1. When tsc returned older value then expected?
2. When the timer expired?
3. In any other time?

Thanks

>Do we know when poll could return us timer event?
Yes. poll() returns timer event when timer expired or cancelled.

1. After timer expired, poll() returns EPOLLIN event.
2. Eventually application calls read(). 
3. During read(), due to unknown reason, timekeeper monotonic clock returns value lesser than the expiry time. This causes read() to return 0.

How do we know we got a false alarm?
I think how the things are going:
1. Our timer expired. The event is fired
2. Our tsc goes back for some reason.
3. When we read the event, the event wasn't fired yet. But it's going to be fired again.
So I think our first alarm with read() = 0 is correct alarm, but the second one is false. :)
But I can be wrong here.

**I've reread our swss code and edited my reply here**

Why I don't like the second option: It will change our API. Currently we have interface for Selectable which has `void readData()`. and we have many implementations for the interface. As soon as we change it, we should:
1. Implement this interface for every selectable in swss-common and swss
3. Change all usage for selectables. Currently I found it select.cpp and notificationConsumer.cpp
After discussion with Arul we decided we can go option 2.
build failure can you check?
Sure. Soon
Corresponding swss changes will be soon in a PR for sonic-swss.
@qiluo-msft @jleveque  modified as requested, please take a look.

It's not "expected". That is clearly defined in API:
http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/read.2.html#RETURN_VALUE
```
       On success, the number of bytes read is returned (zero indicates end
       of file), and the file position is advanced by this number.  It is
       not an error if this number is smaller than the number of bytes
       requested; this may happen for example because fewer bytes are
       actually available right now (maybe because we were close to end-of-
       file, or because we are reading from a pipe, or from a terminal), or
       because read() was interrupted by a signal.  See also NOTES.

       On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set appropriately.  In this
       case, it is left unspecified whether the file position (if any)
       changes.
```

@pavel-shirshov: Understood that read can return >= 0 on success. The problem is with the timerfd, which should only ever return `sizeof(uint64_t)`. If read returns 0, when we can treat it as if it was an EOF, and ignore it. However, if it returns 1 <= retval < sizeof(uint64_t), instead of aborting as Renuka is doing, should we assume that the read() call was interrupted and attempt to read the remaining (sizeof(uint64_t) - retval) bytes?

From http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/timerfd_create.2.html:
```
Operating on a timer file descriptor
       The file descriptor returned by timerfd_create() supports the follow‐
       ing operations:

       read(2)
              If the timer has already expired one or more times since its
              settings were last modified using timerfd_settime(), or since
              the last successful read(2), then the buffer given to read(2)
              returns an unsigned 8-byte integer (uint64_t) containing the
              number of expirations that have occurred.  (The returned value
              is in host byte order—that is, the native byte order for inte‐
              gers on the host machine.)

              If no timer expirations have occurred at the time of the
              read(2), then the call either blocks until the next timer
              expiration, or fails with the error EAGAIN if the file
              descriptor has been made nonblocking (via the use of the
              fcntl(2) F_SETFL operation to set the O_NONBLOCK flag).

              A read(2) fails with the error EINVAL if the size of the sup‐
              plied buffer is less than 8 bytes.

              If the associated clock is either CLOCK_REALTIME or
              CLOCK_REALTIME_ALARM, the timer is absolute
              (TFD_TIMER_ABSTIME), and the flag TFD_TIMER_CANCEL_ON_SET was
              specified when calling timerfd_settime(), then read(2) fails
              with the error ECANCELED if the real-time clock undergoes a
              discontinuous change.  (This allows the reading application to
              discover such discontinuous changes to the clock.)
```

by the way, could you add the link to the design for adding these two tables?

@stcheng  This is the [Appdb-acl-table](https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/blob/master/doc/acl/ACL-High-Level-Design.md#312-app-db) definition.  I will change `APP_ACL_TABLE_NAME` to `APP_ACL_TABLE_TABLE_NAME` and resolve the confilcts.
may i ask which application is writing to these two tables? what's the different purposes for having both configuration ACL table and application ACL table?

Currently MCLAG apps will use these two acl table to dynamically install/uninstall  acl rule for traffic isolation.  Generally the static configured acl rules user defines will be put on cfg table. The dynamic acl rules apps defines will be put on app table.  @stcheng

Change made to 201811 branch on 2/5/2019
Please put an explicit comment in the code as to what we are doing here.

Some background of this issue,  if we have routes flapping quickly (e,g, link flaps),  due to the slow consumer at orchagent, the redis-DB would be consuming more and more memory, and eventually could eat the whole box memory and cause OOM kill of database. 

Looking deeper, we noticed that the issue happened even if the routes are the same set (same prefixes). Since ProducerStateTable itself is a HSET, the routes keys are the same and they should not consume memory increasingly, but rather limited to maximum number of routes.  A few thousands or even 100 thousand routes does not consume much memory.  By looking at the redis debug output, it is clearly showing some buffer are going up during the routes flaps:
//# redis-cli info Clients
//# Clients
connected_clients:241
client_longest_output_list:3625
client_biggest_input_buf:0
blocked_clients:0

//# redis-cli info Clients
//# Clients
connected_clients:241
client_longest_output_list:40067
client_biggest_input_buf:0
blocked_clients:0

//# redis-cli info Memory
//# Memory
used_memory:660227456
used_memory_human:629.64M
used_memory_rss:608448512
used_memory_rss_human:580.26M

And one of the client is not able to consume the published data:
id=216812 addr=/var/run/redis/redis.sock:0 fd=178 name= age=84281 idle=5 flags=U db=0 sub=1 psub=0 multi=-1 qbuf=0 qbuf-free=0 obl=0 oll=41954 omem=845197440 events=rw cmd=subscribe

More debugs show that this is not the app_db PS table but some publish channel. 

Coma back to the code, before the PR,  the publish of the key/value is per request, while after the PR changes, the publish only happens if key set didn't exist before.

With the PR, based on testing, the memory does not build up anymore on Redis even with slow consumer as both ProducerStateTable and Notifications would be capped to maximum number of entries. 

$ sudo redis-cli info clients
//# Clients
connected_clients:241
client_longest_output_list:411
client_biggest_input_buf:0
blocked_clients:0
...
$ sudo redis-cli info clients
//# Clients
connected_clients:241
client_longest_output_list:357
client_biggest_input_buf:0
blocked_clients:0

$ sudo redis-cli info Memory 
//# Memory
used_memory:16743648
used_memory_human:15.97M
used_memory_rss:22810624
used_memory_rss_human:21.75M
